title: Bug 17993: Find/Replace should not replace typed entry with value from history
description:
It would be better if what I type is not replaced with a value from the history. The current behavior seems to be similar to autocomplete, which is common in browsers. In the future, a full autocomplete feature could be provided.

I'm using the F1 build. The Find/Replace dialog (accessed through Edit > Find/Replace...) has a history of recent searches. When I type in the 'Find' or 'Replace With' fields, it searches for entries from a previous search. If it finds one, it replaces what I have typed with the value from the history. The search of the history is case-insensitive, which means that the case of what I have typed may be changed to the case of the value in the history. In some scenarios, this makes it impossible to perform find or replace operations.

For me, it is very common to perform operations like this. I think the current behavior should be changed to something more simple which allows the full range of find and replace operations to be performed, while still respecting the case of what the user types. Until then, I think the feature should be removed.

To reproduce:
1. Open a document so that Edit > Find/Replace... becomes available.
2. Enter text in the 'Find' field or 'Replace With' field.
3. Observe that if the entered text matches a value from the history, it is replaced with that value.

The behavior is similar for the 'Replace With' field.
OB: When typing in the 'Find' or 'Replace With' fields in the Find/Replace dialog, if the entered text matches a value from the history, it gets replaced with that value. The search for matching entries is case-insensitive.
EB: When typing in the 'Find' or 'Replace With' fields in the Find/Replace dialog, the entered text should not be replaced with a value from the history. The find and replace operations should work with the full range of possibilities and respect the case of what the user types.
SR:
1. Open a document so that Edit > Find/Replace... becomes available.
2. Enter text in the 'Find' field or 'Replace With' field.
3. Verify that the entered text is not replaced with a value from the history.
4. Perform find and replace operations, ensuring that the full range of possibilities is available and the case of the entered text is respected.

The behavior should be consistent for the 'Replace With' field as well.
